Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "IFormFile bug" (#3304) at aspnet/Home
Opened issue "ExceptionHandlerMiddleware log message too generic" (#3303) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @kanadaj on July 6, 2018 20:43_

Using ASP.NET Core 2.1.1, the error message logged by the ExceptionHandlerMiddleware is far too generic.

It really feels like the default handler should either use `Exception.Message` or the type of the `Exception` as part of the logged message for the sake of being able to identify at least the exception type from the log message.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3247357/42399367-70c9f1a8-8165-11e8-8313-dab6c178cf1a.png)


_Copied from original issue: aspnet/Mvc#8025_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "authenication and AAD with signalR" (#2603) at aspnet/SignalR
Opened issue "SignalR does not seem to use provided id from custom IUserIdProvider" (#2602) at aspnet/SignalR
Events.RelatedBody:
* Microsoft.Azure.SignalR 1.0.0-preview1-10015
* @aspnet/signalr 1.0.0
* Javascript client from Latest Chrome
* Kestrel
* Ubuntu 18.04 (Tried on Windows 10 as well)

Experienced issue:
I use SignalR core with the SingalR Service in Azure, and I would like to tweak how users are mapped since the default `NameIdentifier` claim in my jwt token is not specific enough in my case.

I have created a custom class that implements `IUserIdProvider` and added this as a dependency in my Startup as:   
```
services.AddSignalR().AddAzureSignalR("********");
services.AddSingleton<IUserIdProvider, MyCustomProvider>();
````
I can see that my custom provider is called but it looks like the default `NameIdentifier` is used anyway.
It does not matter what I return from my `GetUserId` method.
Are there any known issues regarding this or do you have any idea what is the problem here?

Thanks!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Extend ViewComponents shared view location." (#6426) at aspnet/Mvc
Closed issue "Api Response should have a way to represent a default response type" (#6828) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody: Swagger \ OpenAPI has a way to represent a `default` error response for all errors. See https://swagger.io/docs/specification/describing-responses#default. We don't have a good way to represent this. For the time being, we're resorting to using `StatusCode=0` to indicate this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "RoleClaims: Usages Designs and Questions" (#1859) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
**Maybe I am missing something**, but I find RoleClaims "badly considered", even neglected.

Whereas Role Claims/Group Claims are **essential for intranet Apps (Windows authentication), and "general" group membership**—without them, it will lead to some repetitive code, **or to write custom Identity**— I find that they are not "user friendly".

So I have some questions, and will share some thoughts.

## Usages of RoleClaims
What is the purpose of RoleClaims in Identity?
- How to use them **accordingly to you**?
    - This subject is not documented.
    - I find no sample on github;
- Do you consider to remove them in the future?
    - It seems—badly considered—and that it could be…
    - if yes, how you will replace them? (How??? Knowing that, most of us cannot rely on something "ephemeral")

## Design and limitations
If we want to use RoleClaims as it should (in a many-to-many relationship) like AspNetUserRoles table, we find that some pieces are missing…
- No documentation…
- No many-to-many relationship table between Roles and Claims, ready to use;
- Weird property `public virtual TKey RoleId { get; set; }` in `IdentityRoleClaim`;
- Not ready to use in `AuthorizationHandler` as
    - Nothing ready to use in `ClaimsIdentity` and `ClaimsPrincipal` classes, to get RoleClaims;
    - If we use DI in `AuthorizationHandler`, we have to register the `AuthorizationHandler` as `scope` to get access to RoleManager/UserManager, etc…

## Consequences
- We have to do some choice: singleton vs RoleClaims access;
- Write many-to-many relationship table between Roles and RoleClaims;
- Keeping useless property `public virtual TKey RoleId { get; set; }` in `IdentityRoleClaim`;

**But If we want to get something nice and simple, particularly with `AuthorizationHandler`:**
- With or without the current RoleClaims Api, we have to dive into Identity Customization, **because nothing is ready to use as it should be…**

## Conclusion
Can you reconsider the importance of RoleClaims in Identity, and provide us "a better design"?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager is not doing a check if the email is already confirmed" (#1861) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody: Hey. Shouldn't the **`ConfirmEmailAsync`** method in **`UserManager`** do a check if the email is already confirmed? Is it an adequate behaviour to successfully confirm an already confirmed email? It basically don't change the outcome in any way(and the operation can be considered as successful), because the email confirmation state stays the same, but shouldn't it be considered an exceptional behaviour and be accompanied with an error?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Re-implement received GOAWAY support" (#2703) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7540#section-6.8

There's a rudimentary implementation for processing received GOAWAY frames that immediately aborts all streams and then closes the connection. GOAWAY is supposed to indicate a graceful shutdown, not an immediate abort. After a GOAWAY you're only guaranteed that the client will not open any new streams. They may continue to send you Window Updates, Pings, Data frames, etc., and the server may continue to send responses. Once all responses are complete then the server can send its own GOAWAY and close the connection. If the client really wants to abort the connection they will send a GOAWAY and then close the socket.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Convert Write100ContinueAsync to sync" (#2700) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
IHttpOutputProducer.Write100ContinueAsync is only ever called synchronously from HttpProtocol.ProduceContinue. It can and should be reimplemented synchronously.

https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/blob/2191327b59f87f23f69fff2ac0dba9e58b67141b/src/Kestrel.Core/Internal/Http/HttpProtocol.cs#L969

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unable to publish when using Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor" (#1076) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
After I upgraded my solution from asp.net core 2.0 to 2.1, I'm not able to publish my web app from Visual Studio, although it can build.

During the upgrade I've changed SDK in one of my class libraries to **Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor**, but now I'm getting a lot of errors and if project references were not recognized in this library when publishing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support for multi-line string values" (#1057) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @alexvy86 on August 3, 2017 21:11_

I'm using Akka.NET in a project and the way they do configuration is not-quite-JSON, but still a hierarchical structure, which I haven't been able to successfully integrate into `appsettings.json`. The only way I've been able to do it is to collapse all of their hierarchy into a single-line string value, which makes it a bit of a pain to work with.

For now I just put the whole thing as CDATA in an XML file and use the `AddXmlFile()` extension from `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Xml` to read it, but it'd be preferable to have it in `appsetings.json`.

_Copied from original issue: aspnet/Configuration#703_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unable to publish when using Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor" (#1076) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "For contributors: branch name changes in ASP.NET Core repos" (#309) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: Over the coming weeks, we are planning on making the following changes to most projects in https://github.com/aspnet that are used to build ASP.NET Core. * We will create a branch named "release/2.2". Work on this branch will be part of [ASP.NET Core 2.2](https://github.com/aspnet/Announcements/issues/307) * We will rename the "dev" branch to "master". This is part of aligning aspnet repos with the branch naming used by other Microsoft teams. * We will change the default branch to "master" on GitHub. * Update the product branding on "master" to 3.0. Work on this branch will eventually become part of [ASP.NET Core 3.0](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2018/05/07/net-core-3-and-support-for-windows-desktop-applications/) To help us prevent too much drift between release/2.2 and master, we will enable some automation to merge all changes from release/2.2 into master (3.0). ## FAQ This change may affect the way you help contribute to ASP.NET Core. As a result of this change and dicussion within our team, we've anticipated at least two questions you may have. #### Which branch should I use for my work? #### I opened my PR to the wrong branch. What should I do? You can edit a PR’s target branch. ## Questions? Comments? This issue is locked to reduce noise on this repo. Please use https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/3278 for questions and comments. Thanks, Nate

Issues.Title: ExceptionHandlerMiddleware log message too generic
Issues.Body:
_From @kanadaj on July 6, 2018 20:43_

Using ASP.NET Core 2.1.1, the error message logged by the ExceptionHandlerMiddleware is far too generic.

It really feels like the default handler should either use `Exception.Message` or the type of the `Exception` as part of the logged message for the sake of being able to identify at least the exception type from the log message.

Issues.Title: Instability the path of @Html.Partial("path") method according to Os version
Issues.Body:
Hi,

    Me and my friend just joined a team recently. Everyone have same dotnet sdk with the latest version and projects are being developing with c#. Somewhere in our web project, we have 

> @Html.Partial("Layout/javascript")

 method in the _Layout.cshtml file that is in the default directory. Path is right, there is a Layout folder and it includes "Javascript.cshtml" file. Me and my friend are using Ubuntu 16.04.4 with latest version. When we fetched the repository and tried to run this project, it gave us an error that is saying there is no "Layout/javascript" file, we thought its case sensitive and changed the method to @Html.Partial("Layout/Javascript") and it worked. 
    But the problem is that former developers had no problem on their codes. @Html.Partial("Layout/javascript") method was working on their computers. One of them is using MacOs version: 10.13.5, Kernel version: Darwin 17.6.0 and one of them is using Ubuntu version: 16.04.(1 or 2, not sure) in their computers. When one of them has updated his Ubuntu from "16.04.(1 or 2, not sure)" to "16.04.4" the latest version, he got the same error that is saying couldn't find the "Layout/javascript" file. Also another developer with the latest version of linux mint "18.03 slvia" gets the same case sensivity error. This instability makes us curious. Please tell us what causes this and let us know that we need to take precautions. Thank you.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Instability the path of @Html.Partial("path") method according to Os version" (#3300)

Issues.Title: Certain Sequence of Text/HTML on Razor Page Results in Error "rzc generate exited with code 1" During Build
Issues.Body:
_From @robinwilson16 on July 3, 2018 19:3_ I have discovered a strange bug where certain text and HTML I add to a Razor page results in the following error and the project failing to build and this did not occur on 2.0 as I am migrating the existing pages: ``` rzc generate exited with code 1. WebApplication1 C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\NuGetFallbackFolder\microsoft.aspnetcore.razor.design\2.1.1\build\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.AspNetCore.Razor.Design.CodeGeneration.targets 121 ``` I can make the error go away by just changing the formatting slightly such as removing some of the blank line breaks, removing the emoticon or removing the img tag but either way the syntax is valid. Also until I get rid of the error I cannot create any new razor pages either as get the same error. I did wonder if there was some special character but as changing any bits of the text cause it to work again it seems to just not like this exact sequence of text. I can replicate by creating a new .NET Core Web Application in VS.NET (latest build) and pasting the following into one of the Razor pages exactly as is: ```

Metro Centre Auto World is a family owned and run business.

We pride ourselves on the great service we provide to all of our customers.

Been turned down for finance? We can help with finance options tailored to suit your needs.

We understand that buying a car can be a daunting prospect, so we strive to make the buying process as simple and hassle-free as possible.

But don't just take our word for it, see what some of our customers have to say about us...

💬 See what people are saying
``` I just need to remove a line break between any of the sets of P tags and the build is successful. The page did have more content on it but I reduced it down to find which bit was triggering the error. _Copied from original issue: dotnet/corefx#30816_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Certain Sequence of Text/HTML on Razor Page Results in Error "rzc generate exited with code 1" During Build" (#3294)

Issues.Title: Remove support for the implicit package version of Microsoft.AspNetCore.App
Issues.Body: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App, unlike normal NuGet packages, represents a shared framework. This means the package provides: * A) The minimum expected version of of the ASP.NET Core shared runtime (found in C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App\$(PackageVersion)) * B) A baseline of assemblies versions which the SDK expects to find in the shared runtime * C) References assemblies for the compiler * D) Implementations assemblies for self-contained deployments There is tension between these as we want the lowest possible version of (A) to simplify deployment concerns, the highest version of (D) for security updates and patch fixes, and a version of (B) and (C) compatible with both (A) and (D). We attempted to solve this tension in 2.1.0 by optimizing for (A) and hiding the package version from users and keeping it low, pinned to 2.1.0. That [made it difficult](https://github.com/aspnet/Universe/issues/1180) to use packages which shared dependencies with the shared framework. In 2.1.1, we tried to fix this by easing off the restrictions and allowing package upgrades, but means users unintentionally upgrade out of the baseline (B), and end up with redundant copies of binaries in their publish output. After lots of design discussion reviewing half a dozen alternatives, we think it will be better in the long run to back to reverse course and encourage users to use an explicit version on the PackageReference to Microsoft.AspNetCore.App, and it regularly update it to latest. ## Proposed changes * Update `dotnet new` templates to include the latest Microsoft.AspNetCore.App package version in the .csproj file. * Update Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web to warn when Microsoft.AspNetCore.App is missing a package version. * Text: `The package reference to Microsoft.AspNetCore.App is missing the Version attribute. Defaulting to Version="2.1.1".`. * Remove "IsImplicitlyDefined" = true from Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web. This unblocks the NuGet UI from displaying updates. Before: After: ## Downsides One of the primary reasons for making the version implicit was to simplify deployment. As history since 2.0.0 has taught us, our users that updating a PackageReference should be sufficient to use the newest version of ASP.NET Core. However, there is one more step required: users need to install a compatible shared runtime. This step is not obvious from the NuGet Package UI in VS, and error messages indicating the missing runtime are sometimes hidden (e.g. IIS Express, Test Explorer). ## Proposed enhancement * Update Microsoft.NET.Sdk to produce a warning when compiling for a .NET Core shared framework which is not present on the machine (cc @dsplaisted @nguerrera). * Text: `This project is compiling for Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 2.1.3, but a compatible runtime was not found. .NET Core runtimes can be installed from https://aka.ms/dotnet-download` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2696087/42192301-db33105c-7e1c-11e8-912a-60b601fe7414.png) cc @DamianEdwards @davidfowl @JunTaoLuo @vijayrkn
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Remove support for the implicit package version of Microsoft.AspNetCore.App " (#3292)

Issues.Body:
Per discussion with the engineering teams, we should make the following changes.

* Create a branch named "release/2.2".

Issues.Title: Ajax CDN is missing a bundled version of the core client library used in ASP.NET
Issues.Body:
This one is similar to: #3285 

The Bootstrap 4.* authors added version of the JavaScript Bootstrap library bundled with its core dependency for tooltips/pop-overs/etc: 'popper.js':
https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.1/getting-started/contents/#js-files

The published version of the Bootstrap on the MS Ajax CDN seems to be missing the `bundle` version:
https://ajax.aspnetcdn.com/ajax/bootstrap/4.0.0/bootstrap.js
https://ajax.aspnetcdn.com/ajax/bootstrap/4.0.0/bootstrap.bundle.js

Thanks!

Issues.Title: Things may consider for Localization 3.0.0
Issues.Body:
There 're some points I'd like to share with you guys, that may we consider for localization 3.0.0:

- Move resource manager classes into a new namespace `Microsoft.Extensions.Localization.ResourceManager`, this is useful for APIs organization and if we add another localization source provider such as `POStringLocalizer` also to align with other ASP.NET Core repos such as Configuration, Security .. etc
- Use ASP.NET Core `MemoryCache` instead of using `IResourceNamesCache` & `ResourceNamesCache`, no need to reivent the wheel, while we are have a rich and tested APIs
- Using `ResourceManager` resource set directly from within `ResourceManagerStringLocalizer` instead of introducing `IResourceStringProvider` & `ResourceManagerStringProvider`. If I'm not wrong those APIs was introduced because the lack and limitation of the `ResourceManager` resource set APIs support in .NET Core in the past
- Support Pluralization APIs out-of-the-box
- Support another localization resource provider such as `POStringLocalizer`
- I think we need to revisit the `IStringLocalizerFactory` the `Create(baseName, assembly)` is not used except testing, also the `Create()` needs to be more generic rather it is used for `ResourceManager`
- These are some that raised on my head and I will modify the list if I have other once ..

/cc @mkArtakMSFT
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Things may consider for Localization 3.0.0" (#3289)

Issues.Title: Cannot debug client-side code in VS Code with out-of-the-box SPA project.
Issues.Body:
I've created a new React SPA for ASP.NET Core 2.1.

Out of the box, if I open the `ClientApp` directory in VS Code I can then hit F5 to launch Chrome (using the Chrome debugger extension).

However, when I set breakpoints, each breakpoint is greyed out with the following message:

````
Unverified breakpoint, Breakpoints set but not yet bound
````

I'm fairly certain this is an issue with the `launch.json` configuration, specifically the `webRoot` (and possibly the `sourceMapPathOverrides`) property.

Here's the standard `launch.json` that I'm using:

````
{
    // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes.
    // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
    // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Chrome against localhost",
            "url": "https://localhost:44311",
            "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}",
            "sourceMapPathOverrides": {
                "webpack:///./*": "${webRoot}/*",
                "webpack:///src/*": "${webRoot}/*",
                "webpack:///*": "*",
                "webpack:///./~/*": "${webRoot}/node_modules/*",
                "meteor://💻app/*": "${webRoot}/*"
            }
        }
    ]
}
````

And the output of calling `.scripts` in a debug session is:

````
› https://localhost:44311/static/js/bundle.js
````

Is the assumption that it's an issue with `launch.json` correct?  If so, what is the correct configuration out of the box?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cannot debug client-side code in VS Code with out-of-the-box SPA project." (#3287)

Issues.Title: Please include deleting ASP.NET Core Runtime in Uninstaller
Issues.Body:
_From @JunTaoLuo on June 29, 2018 21:42_

We had huge problems with dotnet core SDK 2.1.301 so we went back to 2.1.300. But the uninstaller did not delete the ASP.NET Core runtime.

Because the runtime was still there after we uninstalled 2.1.301 we got some very strange problems.

So my expectation is, that everything that an installer installs on the system will be deleted by the uninstaller. I had to delete manually the folder in `C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App`

Thx

Issues.Title: .Net Core template based on BS4 are missing core dependency on MS Ajax CDN
Issues.Body:
The ASP.NET templating team is working on update of client/design dependencies to BS4
https://github.com/aspnet/templating/pull/595

There is a problem with update in my opinion:
- the template authors use Ajax CDN for production (hosted) dependencies
- the Ajax CDN is missing core Bootstrap 4 dependency required for tooltips/pop-overs/modals, etc

e.g. see comment on this non-merged, staled PR:
https://github.com/aspnet/templating/pull/476#issue-181709995

> also upgrade libs to latest version. used cdnjs instead of the MS cdn since popper.js is missing (bs4 dependency) and because MS cdn doesn't show integrated strings.

If possible, can someone add that core dependency to Ajax CDN resources (and later update docs)?
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/ajax/cdn/overview#Bootstrap_Releases_on_the_CDN_14

To re-iterate issue: 
- some features of BS 4 depends on JavaScript
- if JavaScript components are to be used (think: business-line apps) the BS needs:
- jQuery, Popper.js and its own library ('bootstrap.js')

The page author can use`bootstrap.bundle.js` to use Popper.js bundled, but that is just an option (and she or he needs to know what is the difference between `bootstrap.js` and `bootstrap.bundle.js`)

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".Net Core template based on BS4 are missing core dependency on MS Ajax CDN" (#3285)

Issues.Title: .NET core - route behavior difference from Windows and Linux
Issues.Body:
I am using this route on Windows with .NET core:

```
routes.MapRoute("api", "{action}/{id?}", new { controller = "API", action = "Index" });
```

Everything works great in console app or in IIS. Example url: http://localhost/action/parameter, calls into APIController controller class.

When running the same code on Linux (Ubuntu 18.04 in this case), I get a 404 error for every call. Changing the route to this fixes it:

```
routes.MapRoute("api", "/{action}/{id?}", new { controller = "API", action = "Index" });
```

Note that the new route starts with a forward slash, which is required on Linux. It would be nice if the forward slash was optional on all platforms.

Thanks very much!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".NET core - route behavior difference from Windows and Linux" (#3284)

for moving web templates dependencies and design forward. 
There is a problem that version of main library used as dependency (code and design) released by library authors is current at 4.1.1:
https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/
while the version of the same library hosted by MS at Ajax CDN is still locked on the 4.0.0 (the very first version from 4.*)
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/ajax/cdn/overview#Bootstrap_Releases_on_the_CDN_14

How can we trigger some update on MS CDN?

Thanks!

In some cases, when someone tries to access a page which relies on `HttpContext.Request.Path`, the following error is thrown:

The path in 'value' must start with '/'.
```
The URL looks something like this:
```
https://www.domain.com/fiction/18594/cultivating-civilization/chapter/228753/151-traitors

This seems to work for most users, but with rare exceptions. I'm not sure what exact conditions trigger this, as I see no headers or such that could justify this.

Issues.Title: After package upgrade to 2.1.1 server/app fails to start
Issues.Body:
So I just upgraded packages for ASP.NET Core (the default ones, that come with the project template) from 2.1.0 to 2.1.1 and suddenly the app did not start again..

Found the following error in event log:
Application 'MACHINE/WEBROOT/APPHOST/TRIP.ADMIN' with physical root 'H:\...\App.Admin\' failed to start process with commandline 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\Common7\IDE\Extensions\Microsoft\Web Tools\ProjectSystem\VSIISExeLauncher.exe -argFile "C:\Users\Marko\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp4D17.tmp"', ErrorCode = '0x80004005 : 0.

Then tried some Google searches and stumled upon this
https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/24412/dotnetexe-instantly-crashes-when-debugging-aspnet.html

saying that it could be SDK related so I went and installed SDK 2.1.301 on the machine (previously had 2.1.300 running) and now magically the app works.

My question is: whatever happened to saying that ASP.NET Core is self contained and we don't have to worry about updating computers/servers? I guess it's not quite like that, ha..
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "After package upgrade to 2.1.1 server/app fails to start" (#3281)

Issues.Title: [question] angular project should be in same project or separate
Issues.Body:
I was reading how the angular template is implemented, I am seeing that the frontend is sitting in the same project, I wonder if it's the recommended way of architecting the angular project with asp.net core or not? 

in cloud architecture, it's good to separate part of an application to scale separately, but since the frontend really doesn't cost much to server files it usually end up to host on same server. 
what are the benefits that i should expect from keeping the angular and .net together?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[question] angular project should be in same project or separate" (#3280)

Issues.Title: Diagnostic Logs Level set in Azure does not work
Issues.Body:
We are running an ASP.NET Core 2.1 app in Azure App Service with logging set in appsettings.Development.json and apnetcore_environment set to development. We have noticed that when we make a change to the Diagnostic Logs Level it does not make a difference in the logging output. We’ve tested this looking at the Log Stream output and with/without application restarts. Is this supposed to be the preferred behavior? In the documentation it seems to imply this should work ok without any code changes in .NET Core (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/fundamentals/logging/?view=aspnetcore-2.1&tabs=aspnetcore2x#azure-app-service-provider).

From the docs: 
“If targeting .NET Core, don't install the provider package or explicitly call AddAzureWebAppDiagnostics. The provider is automatically available to the app when the app is deployed to Azure App Service.

When you deploy to an App Service app, the app honors the settings in the Diagnostic Logs section of the App Service page of the Azure portal. When these settings are updated, the changes take effect immediately without requiring a restart or redeployment of the app.”
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Diagnostic Logs Level set in Azure does not work" (#3279)

### Please consider the following before filing an issue

* If you are using NuGet Packages that start with `Microsoft.AspNet.SignalR`, use the issue tracker at https://github.com/SignalR/SignalR to report the issue. This 
repository is for packages that start with `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR` (and NPM packages that start with `@aspnet/signalr`)

### Please include as much of the following as you can in your bug report

* Versions of Server-Side NuGet Packages:
* Versions of Client-Side NuGet/NPM Packages:
* Are you using the C# client or the JavaScript client:
* The Server you are using (Kestrel/HttpSysServer/IIS/IIS Express/Azure Web App/etc.): 
* The Operating System on the Server (Windows/Linux/macOS):
* The Operating System on the Client (Windows/Linux/macOS):
* The Browser on the client, if using the JavaScript client (IE/Chrome/Edge/Firefox/etc.):
* Please use the Diagnostics Guide at https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/wiki/Diagnostics-Guide to collect server-side and client-side logs and network traces if possible. Please **do not** put the traces and logs in the Issue text as they are quite large. The Diagnostics Guide describes how to attach them to the issue.

When in doubt, feel free to file the issue, we're happy to help answer questions. We also suggest using the `asp.net-core-signalr` tag on StackOverflow to ask questions.

Issues.Title: StreamItem InvocationId cleanup
Issues.Body:
Previously, stream items were returned from the server in response to an invocation, and so carried an invocation id for routing purposes.

Now, stream items can be sent to the server, and are sorted based on stream id.  Regardless of direction, all id values are stored under the `InvocationId` field on `StreamItem`. This is poor naming and rather misleading.

Possible solutions include:
- StreamItem has two fields, `StreamId` and `InvocationId`, only one of which can be filled at a time
- StreamItem has one field, `RoutingId`, which is used both ways. This breaks backwards compatibility.
- Make a new class `StreamParameterItem` that's identical to stream item but has a `StreamId` field instead.

None of these solutions feels very clean.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "StreamItem InvocationId cleanup" (#2592)

Issues.Title: @aspnet/signalr - make connection id available
Issues.Body:
I have a reactive angular app where its services contain observables to allow components to react to certain events. i.e. saving a form will cause the adjacent index component to reload. This all works reasonably well, until I have added SignalR into the mix to broadcast these same events between clients. Essentially the same services/observables used to perform the intra-client events are now emitting events when the socket receives the respective event too. 

The problem i now have is that the components receive two events per action, one raised internally when the http request completes (client service -> obserable -> component), and the other from the socket (controller -> hubcontext -> client hubconnection -> client service -> observable -> component).
I need both event sources as I don't want to rely on the socket to perform intra-app communication and it also provides a consistent way, from the subscribing components perspective, to get events.

Ideally I would like to ignore the client who sent the http from getting the signalr message so dont have to do any hacky buffering and grouping on the client app. A good solution would be to include the signalr connection id as a header in the http request which i could then use to filter hubcontext clients.

In the meantime, accessing the connection id via sending an initial message to the client will suffice. Seems odd that the connection id is unavailable client-side. Using groups only works in certain situations.

Appreciate any feedback.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "@aspnet/signalr - make connection id available" (#2590)

Issues.Title: RoleClaims: Usages Designs and Questions
Issues.Body:
**Maybe I am missing something**, but I find RoleClaims "badly considered", even neglected.

Whereas Role Claims/Group Claims are **essential for intranet Apps (Windows authentication), and "general" group membership**—without them, it will lead to some repetitive code, **or to write custom Identity**— I find that they are not "user friendly".

So I have some questions, and will share some thoughts.

## Usages of RoleClaims
What is the purpose of RoleClaims in Identity?
- How to use them **accordingly to you**?
    - This subject is not documented.
    - I find no sample on github;
- Do you consider to remove them in the future?
    - It seems—badly considered—and that it could be…
    - if yes, how you will replace them? (How??? Knowing that, most of us cannot rely on something "ephemeral")

## Design and limitations
If we want to use RoleClaims as it should (in a many-to-many relationship) like AspNetUserRoles table, we find that some pieces are missing…
- No documentation…
- No many-to-many relationship table between Roles and Claims, ready to use;
- Weird property `public virtual TKey RoleId { get; set; }` in `IdentityRoleClaim`;
- Not ready to use in `AuthorizationHandler` as
    - Nothing ready to use in `ClaimsIdentity` and `ClaimsPrincipal` classes, to get RoleClaims;
    - If we use DI in `AuthorizationHandler`, we have to register the `AuthorizationHandler` as `scope` to get access to RoleManager/UserManager, etc…

## Consequences
- We have to do some choice: singleton vs RoleClaims access;
- Write many-to-many relationship table between Roles and RoleClaims;
- Keeping useless property `public virtual TKey RoleId { get; set; }` in `IdentityRoleClaim`;

**But If we want to get something nice and simple, particularly with `AuthorizationHandler`:**
- With or without the current RoleClaims Api, we have to dive into Identity Customization, **because nothing is ready to use as it should be…**

## Conclusion
Can you reconsider the importance of RoleClaims in Identity, and provide us "a better design"?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "RoleClaims: Usages Designs and Questions" (#1859)

Issues.Title: ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager is not doing a check if the email is already confirmed
Issues.Body: Hey. Shouldn't the **`ConfirmEmailAsync`** method in **`UserManager`** do a check if the email is already confirmed? Is it an adequate behaviour to successfully confirm an already confirmed email? It basically don't change the outcome in any way(and the operation can be considered as successful), because the email confirmation state stays the same, but shouldn't it be considered an exceptional behaviour and be accompanied with an error?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager is not doing a check if the email is already confirmed" (#1861)

Issues.Title: ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager does a ton of unrelated actions and validations
Issues.Body: **`ConfirmEmailAsync`** in **`UserManager`** should validate a token and set the **`EmailConfirmed`** flag to true. However, in the current implementation, we save the context changes through invoking the **`UpdateUserAsync`** method. It re-sets the Normalized username and email and then calls the **`ValidateUserAsync`** method, which in turn runs the user validators. It is not that great of an overhead, but is this really necessary or is it just an architectural trade-off?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ConfirmEmailAsync in UserManager does a ton of unrelated actions and validations" (#1856)

Issues.Title: What is considered best practice for disabling / deactivating users?
Issues.Body:
I would define disabling / deactivating a user as having a property held against that user which prevented them from being able to log into the application when the property had been set to a certain value.

We are building an admin section where admin members can disable / re-enable users as required.

The options I have identified:

1. Set email confirmed to false. To re-activate a user, regenerate an email confirmation link for them.
Or
2. Set Lockout Enabled to True and Lockout End to DateTime.Max
Or
3. Add IsEnabled field to AspNetUsers (default to True) and override SignInManager to check value is True before returning a Success result.

Are there any other options / which is the most recommended?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "What is considered best practice for disabling / deactivating users?" (#1858)

Issues.Title: Documentation for two factor (2FA) TOTP support
Issues.Body:
ASP.NET Identity 2.x includes support for two factor TOTP authentication using an authenticator on the smartphone. I couldn't find it documented anywhere. All I could find is configuring two factor auth with SMS Code, even though the docs specifically refer to TOTP as more appropriate:

From [docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/identity-enable-qrcodes?view=aspnetcore-2.1):
>  Two factor authentication (2FA) authenticator apps, using a Time-based One-time Password Algorithm (TOTP), are the industry recommended approach for 2FA. 2FA using TOTP is preferred to SMS 2FA.

Since TOTP does not need to be configured separately and is included by default in identity razor class library, it is not a big issue, but I suppose it would make sense to document that:

* it is enabled by default
* how to disable it
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Documentation for two factor (2FA) TOTP support" (#1850)

Issues.Title: Scaffolding Identity code?
Issues.Body:
Hey guys, quick question. One of the older blogs ([this one](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/webdev/2018/03/02/aspnetcore-2-1-identity-ui/)) mentions that we should be able to also scaffold the "old" Identity (like normal controllers and views to which are all sensible and sane MVC people used to) - quoting the linked post:

> If you want the flexibility of having the identity code in your app, you can use the new identity scaffolder to add it back.

So at least that is how I understood it. Is this already implemented, has it been dropped or what? If it is a thing already, how can I access it when creating a new project? Or is there at least any real explanation of the changes, how does this new Identity UI work and how to use it? You don't possibly expect all users to read through your repo and API just to understand how to create and extend a damn login or basic application user functionality, do you?

_As a little friendly side note, reworking a thing like Identity so much from 2.0 to 2.1 without an obvious reason or any gains from user perspective and releasing it with piss-poor documentation is probably one of the main causes why so many people are still reluctant to transition to Core. This instability, fluctuation and immaturity of Core is just killing._
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scaffolding Identity code?" (#1840)

Issues.Title: Razor Pages _ViewImports documentation could be more clear
Issues.Body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/mvc/razor-pages/?view=aspnetcore-2.1&tabs=visual-studio#using-layouts-partials-templates-and-tag-helpers-with-razor-pages

The part of this documentation that details the `@namespace` declaration could be made more clear. It has led some people to believe `@namespace` should be used as though it is a `using` statement. See the linked StackOverflow answer below for an example of this. I believe part of the reason it isn't clear, is because it doesn't explain `@using` directives in the context of a `_ViewImports` file.

In short, the wording could be made more clear, and a section should be added detailing `@using` directives in the context of a `_ViewImports` file.

Issues.Title: Re-implement received GOAWAY support
Issues.Body:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7540#section-6.8

There's a rudimentary implementation for processing received GOAWAY frames that immediately aborts all streams and then closes the connection. GOAWAY is supposed to indicate a graceful shutdown, not an immediate abort. After a GOAWAY you're only guaranteed that the client will not open any new streams. They may continue to send you Window Updates, Pings, Data frames, etc., and the server may continue to send responses. Once all responses are complete then the server can send its own GOAWAY and close the connection. If the client really wants to abort the connection they will send a GOAWAY and then close the socket.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Re-implement received GOAWAY support" (#2703)

Issues.Title: AuthenticationException with Client Cert Auth, only in Chrome
Issues.Body:
Hi,

I'm not quite sure if this is the right repository for this, excuse me if it isn't.

I'm having issues implementing client certificate authentication in ASP.NET Core using Kestrel.
More specifically, I'm getting an exception (System.Security.Authentication.AuthenticationException) when connecting to the server via Chrome with a client certificate. Using Firefox or Edge/IE with the same client certificate works fine. 
When digging into it using Wireshark, the only real difference I can find is that Firefox and Edge are using ecdsa_secp256r1_sha256 as the signature algorithm in the Certificate Verify message while Chrome uses ecdsa_secp384r1_sha384.

This is the stack trace when connecting via Chrome:

> Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel[0]

>    at System.Net.Security.SslState.EndProcessAuthentication(IAsyncResult result)
>    at System.Net.Security.SslStream.EndAuthenticateAsServer(IAsyncResult asyncResult)
>    at System.Threading.Tasks.TaskFactory`1.FromAsyncCoreLogic(IAsyncResult iar, Func`2 endFunction, Action`1 endAction, Task`1 promise, Boolean requiresSynchronization)
> --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
>    at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
>    at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
>    at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Https.Internal.HttpsConnectionAdapter.<InnerOnConnectionAsync>d__12.MoveNext()
> --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---

>    at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
>    at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter`1.GetResult()
>    at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.FrameConnection.<ApplyConnectionAdaptersAsync>d__50.MoveNext()

Is the signature algorithm supported here? 

Any other ideas what could cause this? 

Chrome is not really helping in debugging this as the only thing it is reporting is ERR_CONNECTION_CLOSED.

Issues.Title: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core depends simultaneously on both System.Numerics.Vectors nuget package version 4.4.0 and 4.5.0 - the wrong one can end up in the bin dir causing programs not to start
Issues.Body:
`Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core 2.1.1` depends on nuget package `System.Numerics.Vectors 4.5.0` (assembly is actually System.Numerics.Vectors 4.1.4.0)
*aside: I wish microsoft would please stop mismatching nuget and assembly versions, it makes dependency issues incredibly hard to track down and is super confusing*

`Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core 2.1.1` also depends on package `System.Memory 4.5.1` which in turn depends on `System.Numerics.Vectors 4.4.0` (assembly version 4.1.3.0)

Reference: https://www.fuget.org/packages/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core/2.1.1

Note: aspnetcore 2.1.0 also has this same issue.

This manifests itself in our product (running on desktop framework 4.6.1 targeting netstandard2.0) as randomly sometimes getting different versions of `System.Numerics.Vectors` copied into our debug\bin or release\bin directory. We have an assembly binding redirect to target `System.Numerics.Vectors 4.1.4.0`, which mostly works, but sometimes visual studio/msbuild decides to drop 4.1.3.0 into the bin directory instead and our app crashes on startup with an assembly version mismatch exception.

I haven't been able to determine why exactly sometimes S.N.V 4.1.4.0 is copied and why other times 4.1.3.0 is copied.
I tried putting an explict dependency on the S.N.V 4.5.0 nuget package into our application, to try and force 4.1.4.0 to get put there, however it didn't solve the problem and 4.1.3.0 would sometimes get put there.

So - Could the versions of `System.Numerics.Vectors` please be aligned so that kestrel only depends on a single version?

Also, is there any workaround or something we can do to reliably control which version ends up in the bin dir? I don't mind which version it is, but it needs to be consistent or the assembly binding redirect in our app config will be wrong :-(
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core depends simultaneously on both System.Numerics.Vectors nuget package version 4.4.0 and 4.5.0 - the wrong one can end up in the bin dir causing programs not to start" (#2698)

Issues.Title: CPU usage spikes with new Sockets transport
Issues.Body:
I'm having a weird issue with the new "Sockets" transport and I hope you might have some ideas! 

I'm running the latest .NET Core 2.1.1 / ASP.NET Core 2.1.1. I have a single-node Service Fabric cluster for development purposes on Azure (Windows, 2 cores, 16GB RAM) and it runs ~ 60 .NET Core processes (self-contained, `win10-x64`). About half of them are ASP.NET Core applications, the rest is regular console applications with background services. The applications are communicating via the Service Fabric HTTP reverse proxy on localhost (using `HttpClient`).

As it's a dev/demo system, there's almost no load on it. However, when using the new "Sockets" transport, I get high CPU usage (50% - 100%) on the ASP.NET core apps for quite a few seconds every few minutes  which results in a very unstable system.

As you can see in the overall CPU usage of the machine, the system became much more stable after I switched back to `Libuv`. I afterwards tried `Sockets()` with one app and CPU usage became unstable again.
![cpu-overall](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42093084-6d528612-7bab-11e8-916a-628241acb5c5.png)

I've been running PerfView and it shows that the high CPU usage happens around these calls:

```
module Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core <<Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core!Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.Http.HttpProtocol+<ProcessRequests>d__186`1[Microsoft.AspNetCore.Hosting.Internal.HostingApplication+Context].MoveNext()>>
module system.io.pipelines <<system.io.pipelines!System.IO.Pipelines.Pipe+DefaultPipeReader.ReadAsync(value class System.Threading.CancellationToken)>>
module system.io.pipelines <<system.io.pipelines!System.IO.Pipelines.Pipe+DefaultPipeReader.AdvanceTo(value class System.SequencePosition,value class System.SequencePosition)>>
```

Here's some screenshots. Calls by name:
![callsbyname](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092808-8b5ef614-7baa-11e8-8131-0eb0027ea856.png)

Call tree: 
![calltree-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092871-c4a6c92e-7baa-11e8-9903-aea9000ba569.png)
![calltree-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092872-c7142256-7baa-11e8-90ce-758917eed3a7.png)
![calltree-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092875-c9893742-7baa-11e8-8601-5eb8152f586a.png)

_Process CPU usage with libuv:_
As I've said there's almost no load on the app/system.
![cpu-usage-libuv](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092900-d76e3d08-7baa-11e8-98fe-bf85ee32d3c7.png)

_Process CPU usage with Sockets transport:_
Some spikes just take 1-2 seconds, others take a lot longer.
![cpu-usage-sockets](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4581460/42092892-d2cd05fe-7baa-11e8-8f03-8fca0eafbbdb.png)

Any ideas on a possible cause?

PS: I don't know much about PerfView so I hope that what I've done is not misleading.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CPU usage spikes with new Sockets transport" (#2694)

Issues.Title: Memory limits for embedded server
Issues.Body:
We run several game servers and are trying out kestrel as a way to access stats and perform requests on each server, we do this by embedding kestrel in our normal console app ( net core 2.1 )

The problem we have is that kestrel will eat all of the memory it can get its hands on and if we disable server GC we get other issues with GC causing slowdowns for the game server due to cpu spikes.

Is there any way to run kestrel and define an internal limit for memory? or stop it from just using everything it can find? We need to have a large amount of free memory for the game to run well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Memory limits for embedded server" (#2688)

Issues.Title: Kestrel as a service in Centos 7 .netCore 2.1
Issues.Body:
I am using a centos 7 distribution and i just updated the .netcore sdk to 2.1.301. After the update I have a strang behaivior.:
If my app is runing with dotnet run from cli or console it run as expected and static files are displayed.
If the app is run from Kestrel as a service the app does not find the static files(images/js files) or see them as html/text (css files).
The errors that I'm getting in web browser console are:
Refused to apply style from 'http://localhost:5000/css/site.css' because its MIME type ('text/html') is not a supported stylesheet MIME type, and strict MIME checking is enabled
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 (Not Found) - for images and js files.

I have tried to add Microsoft.AspNetCore.StaticFiles as a package but with no luck.

I have to mention that I did not change the code after upgrade. I had to upgrade the sdk to .net 2.1 because I am using NWebsec.  

kestrel service configuration looks like this:
`   [Unit]
    Description=Example .NET Web API Application running on CentOS 7

    [Service]

    ExecStart=/usr/bin/dotnet /home/user/Release/Website.dll
    Restart=always
    # Restart service after 10 seconds if dotnet service crashes
    RestartSec=10
    SyslogIdentifier=dotnet-example
    User=radu
    Environment=ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT=Production 

    [Install]
    WantedBy=multi-user.target`
As a side note /usr/bin/dotnet is linked to /usr/shared/dotnet/dotnet.
The project was published with dotnet publish -o home/user/Release/ -c Release
I don't understand what is the difference  when I run the app with dotnet run and as a service.

Any ideas how can I make this work?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Kestrel as a service in Centos 7 .netCore 2.1" (#2687)

Issues.Title: Do not send headers or data to reset h2 streams.
Issues.Body:
#2462 @halter73 I still need to finish the logging and error messages, but I wanted to show you the concept first.
Once the client has sent us a reset for a given stream we should stop sending headers or data on that stream. The request continues normally and OnStarting still triggers, you only see the error if you check RequestAborted or pass a cancellable token to WriteAsync.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Do not send headers or data to reset h2 streams." (#2686)

Issues.Title: Kestrel functional tests are flakier in the Win10-Universe build configuration
Issues.Body:
Not sure if this is an issue with the build configuration or the tests themselves. But http://aspnetci/viewType.html?buildTypeId=XPlat_Windows_Win10Universe&tab=buildTypeHistoryList shows recent builds have almost all failed with test failures in the `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.FunctionalTests` namespace.

The failures are not particularly consistent beyond their shared namespace / test project. For example `AddressRegistrationTests` holds many of the failing tests. But, that test class isn't among the culprits for all failed builds and the individual tests vary quite a lot.

I've also seen that some of the sometimes-failing tests are flakier in this particular configuration. For example, http://aspnetci/project.html?projectId=XPlat&testNameId=5785442856196240460&tab=testDetails shows that `AddressRegistrationTests.DefaultsServerAddress_BindsToIPv4` passes 99.8% of the time in all Test build configurations. That rate drops to 98.6% when focusing only on Win10-Universe (http://aspnetci/project.html?tab=testDetails&testNameId=5785442856196240460&projectId=XPlat&buildTypeId=XPlat_Windows_Win10Universe). The success rate also looks much worse in builds from the 21st on.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Kestrel functional tests are flakier in the Win10-Universe build configuration" (#2685)

Issues.Title: Lowercase logic modifies non-letter characters in header names
Issues.Body: The current logic applies the lowercase mask: https://github.com/aspnet/KestrelHttpServer/blob/dev/src/Kestrel.Core/Internal/Http2/HPack/HPackEncoder.cs#L144. But this logic does not check whether the character is a letter and can change non-letter symbols. For example, it would change `^` to `~` in header names. The fix would be to ensure that the lower case mask is only applied for upper case letters. We can also consider checking for invalid characters in the header here as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Lowercase logic modifies non-letter characters in header names" (#2684)

Issues.Title: Use Huffman code in HPackEncoder
Issues.Body: Currently we are using a direct encoding when we encode headers. We can optimize by using Huffman code: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7541#section-2.4.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use Huffman code in HPackEncoder" (#2683)

Issues.Title: Replace locking with EventLoop for response framing
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Replace locking with EventLoop for response framing" (#2681)

Issues.Title: Kestrel server crashes with System.BadImageFormatException: Bad IL format.
Issues.Body:
ASP.NET Core 2.1.0 web application deployed to Windows Azure App Service randomly crashes in production environment and server stops handling resuests, just sending 502.3 errors:
Response: The specified CGI application encountered an error and the server terminated the process.

The problem occurs multiple times in a day, the only way to recover it is to restart Azure App Service. CPU and Memory usage are ok before the crash, no any additional errors or failed requests have been found before crashes.

Issues.Title: Add TLS filter sample
Issues.Body:
This is the last part of HTTP/2 TLS restrictions #2251 
- SHOULD NOT use any of the cipher suites that are listed in the cipher suite black list

Since this is a SHOULD we don't want to add a hardcoded prohibition for it. The list is also 12 pages long and would be expensive to check on each request. Users are better off configuring their TLS provider to refuse these ciphers, but if they need to check for some specific ones they can do that as shown in this sample. 

@blowdart does this look workable?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add TLS filter sample" (#2675)

Issues.Title: Use Razor pages under Microsoft.NET.Sdk
Issues.Body:
I've been trying to implement razor pages in a console application, that's running under `Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"`. 

The controllers work fine, but the Views are never found:
`System.InvalidOperationException: The view 'Index' was not found. The following locations were searched:
   /Views/Home/Index.cshtml
   /Views/Shared/Index.cshtml
   /Pages/Shared/Index.cshtml`

Switching to `<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web">` and everything works. 
Is it possible to use Razor pages under `Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"`?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Use Razor pages under Microsoft.NET.Sdk" (#2462)

Issues.Title: [RazorSdk]: Compilation is not deterministic
Issues.Body:
From https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/issues/7975

#### Is this a Bug or Feature request?: Bug


#### Steps to reproduce (preferably a link to a GitHub repo with a repro project): 

1. Build a project with MVC producing some views with `/p:Deterministic=true` 
2. Copy `Project.Views.dll` and `Project.dll`
3. Build project again using flag
4. Compare the two DLLs to the new build - `Project.dll` will have no difference whereas `Project.Views.dll` will be different


#### Description of the problem:

The razor compiled code is not deterministic. This means that building the same source code twice will result in different outputs.
We use `/p:Deterministic=true` to ensure that our build output is the same for the same source code. This is super helpful in our Service Fabric applications where we do not bump the version number up when the code did not change for a service.

#### Version of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` or `Microsoft.AspNetCore.App` or `Microsoft.AspNetCore.All`: 

2.1.0


It looks like there is a `/deterministic+` flag set in the RazorCoreCompile but that doesn't seem to do what is expected?

Issues.Title: ASP.NET Core tag helpers don't allow me to escape attributes annotated with @
Issues.Body:
Hello guys.

While migrating an existing app, I've noticed that the new tag helpers won't let me escape attributes annotated with  @. In my case, I have an existing MVC 5 app that I'm migrating to the ASP.NET Core. The existing code looked like this:

```html
<form action="@Url.Action(...)" @@submit="save()">
```

The server side is trying to use the shortcut notation for Vue's v-on: and the generated HTML looked like this:

```html
<form action="/..." @submit="save()">
```

When this view got migrated to ASP.NET Core, the code was changed to look like this:

```html
<form asp-action="..." asp-controller="..." @@submit="save()">
```

However, now the @«submit attribute isn't outputted (it's simply discarded from the generated HTML).

Is this a bug? If that is not the case, how can I output attributes annotated with @?

 @Thanks.

Luis
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ASP.NET Core tag helpers don't allow me to escape attributes annotated with @" (#2441)

Issues.Title: Account/ConfirmEmail - NullReferenceException in Error.cshtml when providing incorrect token
Issues.Body:
**Description**
The issue is related to Individual Accounts Authentication template. It seems that providing incorrect authentication code for ConfirmEmail action in AccountController (e.g. token which already expired) should result in displaying error page. However, Razor throws an exception while generating the default error view:

```
NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
AspNetCore._Views_Shared_Error_cshtml+<ExecuteAsync>d__0.MoveNext() in Error.cshtml, line 9
```

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Create new project with Individual Accounts Authentication template.
2. Run the application.
3. Register any user via the registration form.
4. Retrieve UserId of the registered user.
5. Try to confirm email with incorrect token, e.g. http://localhost:PORT/Account/ConfirmEmail?UserId={UserId}&Code=INVALID_CODE

**Further technical details**
It's probably caused by the last line in ConfirmEmail action in AccountController:
```
var result = await _userManager.ConfirmEmailAsync(user, code);
return View(result.Succeeded ? "ConfirmEmail" : "Error");
```

When invalid token is passed, Error view is not provided with `ErrorViewModel`. When `Model` is accessed in 9th line of Error.cshtml (`@if (Model.ShowRequestId)`), it throws NullReferenceException.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Account/ConfirmEmail - NullReferenceException in Error.cshtml when providing incorrect token" (#865)

Issues.Title: IEmailSender should have explicitly named parameters for html vs plain text
Issues.Body:
There have been a number of people reporting bugs about the email confirmation link in the StarterWeb template not working.

This is happening because people implement IEmailSender and don't realize that the message being passed in is html. When they send the email as plain text the confirmation link does not work because of the url encoding.

I think the "message" parameter of SendEmailAsync should be renamed to htmlMessage and possibly should have an additional parameter for "plainTextMessage" and both should be passed in from AccountController.

This would make it more clear to implementors of IEmailSender what kind of string(s) they are dealing with and how to correctly implement it.

related issues:
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2152
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2217
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "IEmailSender should have explicitly named parameters for html vs plain text" (#868)

Issues.Title: Can't compile the devextreme-angular package in the Production mode using the ASP.NET Core 2.0 Angular template
Issues.Body:
This issue relates to the [one](https://github.com/DevExpress/devextreme-angular/issues/534). I've created an Angular application using .NET Core 2.0. The issue is reproducible regardless if I use Visual Studio 2017 15.3 or `dotnet new angular`. Everything works fine in the Development mode. But, once I publish my application with the [DevExtreme Angular](https://github.com/DevExpress/devextreme-angular) package using `dotnet publish -c Release`, I'm getting the following error:

```
      ERROR in ./$$_gendir/~/devextreme-angular/ui/data-grid.ngfactory.ts
      Module parse failed: D:\FromCustomers\GH534\NGCore\NGCore\$$_gendir\node_modules\devextreme-angular\ui\data-grid.ngfactory.ts Unexpected token (63:38)
      You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type.
      | import * as i52 from 'devextreme-angular/core/iterable-differ-helper';
      | import * as i53 from 'devextreme-angular/core/nested-option';
      | export const DxDataGridModuleNgFactory:i0.NgModuleFactory<i1.DxDataGridModule> = i0.╔╡cmf(i1.DxDataGridModule,
      |     ([] as any[]),(_l:any) => {
      |       return i0.╔╡mod([i0.╔╡mpd(512,i0.ComponentFactoryResolver,i0.╔╡CodegenComponentFactoryResolver,
       @ ./$$_gendir/ClientApp/app/components/fetchdata/fetchdata.component.ngfactory.ts 8:0-102
       @ ./$$_gendir/ClientApp/app/app.module.server.ngfactory.ts
       @ ./ClientApp/boot.server.ts
D:\FromCustomers\GH534\NGCore\NGCore\NGCore.csproj(41,5): error MSB3073: The command "node node_modules/webpack/bin/webpack.js --env.prod" exited with code 2.
```

I added

```
"devextreme": "^17.1.5",
"devextreme-angular": "^17.1.5",
```

to the `package.json` file. Then, I added DevExtreme CSS files to the `webpack.config.vendor.js` as

```
const nonTreeShakableModules = [
    'bootstrap',
    'bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css',
    'es6-promise',
    'es6-shim',
    'event-source-polyfill',
    'jquery',
    'devextreme/dist/css/dx.common.css',
    'devextreme/dist/css/dx.light.css'
];
```

If instead of the following line in the webpack.config.js file

```
{ test: /\.ts$/, include: /ClientApp/, use: isDevBuild ? ['awesome-typescript-loader?silent=true', 'angular2-template-loader'] : '@ngtools/webpack' },
```

I use

```
{ test: /\.ts$/, use: isDevBuild ? ['awesome-typescript-loader?silent=true', 'angular2-template-loader'] : '@ngtools/webpack' },
```

or

```
{ test: /\.ts$/, include: /ClientApp/, use: ['awesome-typescript-loader?silent=true', 'angular2-template-loader'] },
```

everything works fine. A similar configuration in a project created using Angular CLI works fine as well.

The attached `NGCore` project illustrates the issue and `test-app` created with Angular CLI illustrates that this works in a standard Angular CLI project after I call `ng eject`.

What can be the problem here? Is it in DevExtreme modules or in your webpack configuration?
[test-app.zip](https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/files/1240256/test-app.zip)
[NGCore.zip](https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/files/1240259/NGCore.zip)

Issues.Title: Sharing Common Files Between Templates
Issues.Body:
I have a ReadMe.html file which I'd like to share between my project templates. The file is mostly the same for all three templates, except that it contains a few symbols common to all my templates. I'd like to keep one copy of this file and use symbols to define template specific sections. ```

Common paragraph...

MyTemplate1 paragraph...

MyTemplate2 paragraph...

``` I can think of a way this might work without any help from the templating engine: Keep a common copy of the file, then copy the file into the template folders as a pre-packaging step in my build script. The disadvantage is that now I have three copies of my file unless I use a .gitignores file but then I have the extra step of having to remove the .gitignores file from the template output. I propose that you should be able to add a file as a link, then mark that file as common in your template.json file. Finally, when generating the project, the file is converted from a linked file, into a real one.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Sharing Common Files Between Templates" (#856)

Issues.Title: File new template error for Windows 8.1 32 bit for individual auth.
Issues.Body:
Steps:

1. Download VS2017 Int Preview and dotnet preview3 on Windows 8.1 32 bit.
2. File new... ASP.NET Core app, Web Application with Individual User Accounts Authorization
3. Run application, try to register a new user

Expected Results: A page would show up saying to apply migrations to the database or the user is registered.
Actual Results: SqlException on the SQL Server not being found. 
![4fce5f97](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8302101/28383504-3b7bf12c-6c76-11e7-91d0-5fe2675924a2.PNG)


The fix I had to do was change the ConnectionStrings' DefaultConnection from mssqllocaldb to ProjectsV12. 

Most likely, we would need to change https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/blob/a594b47c417593d43141d3b4eb2bc41d6ad85f20/src/Rules/StarterWeb/IndividualAuth/appsettings.json#L3 to use a variable for the database.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "File new template error for Windows 8.1 32 bit for individual auth." (#855)

Issues.Title: typescript confiugration file item template
Issues.Body:
When the typescript configuration file is added to a project, by default it is "content" which also by default means it ends up being included in the nuget package when you do a `dotnet pack`. Given that the typescript configuration file is used primarily at build time, I don't think it should be included in a resulting nuget pack by default. Can it be changed to create this in the `csproj`:

```
 <ItemGroup>
    <Content Update="Scripts\tsconfig.json">
      <Pack>false</Pack>
    </Content>
  </ItemGroup>
```

Without this, if another project takes a dependency on this nuget package, you get build errors like this:

```

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	TS18003	Build:No inputs were found in config file 'C:/Users/darrell.tunnell/.nuget/packages/gluon.module.themeswitcher/2.0.0/contentFiles/any/net452/Scripts/tsconfig.json'. Specified 'include' paths were '["**/*"]' and 'exclude' paths were '["node_modules","wwwroot"]'.	Reach.GCv3.Mvc.Module.CompanyLogo	C:\Users\darrell.tunnell\Source\Repos\gc3-website\src\Reach.GCv3.Mvc.Module.CompanyLogo\tsc	1	


```

i.e VS is doscovering the typescript configuration files within referenced nuget packages!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "typescript confiugration file item template" (#854)

Issues.Title: Remove PackageTargetFallback
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove PackageTargetFallback" (#853)

Issues.Title: Clarify password reset sentence in ForgotPassword view
Issues.Body:
The `ForgotPassword.cshtml` view includes a sentence which was missing a comma and reversed the words "reset" and "password".

/cc: @phenning @mlorbetske
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Clarify password reset sentence in ForgotPassword view" (#852)

Issues.Title: File new default names inconsistency.
Issues.Body:
_From @Bartmax on July 24, 2015 2:48_

All items in the file new dialog (client side) default names kind of follows a pattern but it's not consistent:

StyleSheet.css
JavaScript.js
htmlpage.html (all lowercase)
CoffeeScript.coffee
json-schema.json
package.json
etc.

Some must have a specific name (like package.json) while others just reflect the file type. 

I see 2 inconsistencies here:

1) casing is inconsistent.
2) TypeScript it suggest file.ts instead of TypeScript.ts


_Copied from original issue: aspnet/Tooling#118_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "File new default names inconsistency." (#850)

Issues.Title: Wrong CLI command for template installation at nuget.org
Issues.Body:
When I go tu nuget.org to search for some template I got the following page for link https://www.nuget.org/packages/NetEscapades.Templates/

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/350314/26781234/bf4cc98c-49ed-11e7-9e4a-08bb168b6c62.png)

The command instruct to use `Install-Package NetEscapades.Templates` which does not work. 

```
Install-Package NetEscapades.Templates
Install-Package : No match was found for the specified search criteria and package name 'NetEscapades.Templates'. Try Get-PackageSource to see all available registered p ackage sources.
At line:1 char:1
+ Install-Package NetEscapades.Templates
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (Microsoft.Power....InstallPackage:InstallPackage) [Install-Package], Exception
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NoMatchFoundForCriteria,Microsoft.PowerShell.PackageManagement.Cmdlets.InstallPackage
```
The correct command is `dotnet new --install "NetEscapades.Templates::*"`

Will this be fixed in future release?  Which will be the correct CLI command?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Wrong CLI command for template installation at nuget.org" (#848)

Issues.Title: Support for multi-line string values
Issues.Body:
_From @alexvy86 on August 3, 2017 21:11_

I'm using Akka.NET in a project and the way they do configuration is not-quite-JSON, but still a hierarchical structure, which I haven't been able to successfully integrate into `appsettings.json`. The only way I've been able to do it is to collapse all of their hierarchy into a single-line string value, which makes it a bit of a pain to work with.

For now I just put the whole thing as CDATA in an XML file and use the `AddXmlFile()` extension from `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Xml` to read it, but it'd be preferable to have it in `appsetings.json`.

_Copied from original issue: aspnet/Configuration#703_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support for multi-line string values" (#1057)

Issues.Title: Support dotnet watch in launchSettings.json
Issues.Body:
I used to be able to use `dotnet watch` in Visual Studio by adding the following section to `launchSettings.json` and starting the project without debugging using CTRL + F5.

```
    "Kestrel (dotnet watch run)": {
      "commandName": "Executable",
      "executablePath": "C:\\Program Files\\dotnet\\dotnet.exe",
      "commandLineArgs": "watch run",
      "launchBrowser": true,
      "launchUrl": "https://localhost:5001/",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
      }
    },
```

This used to work in ASP.NET Core 1.1 but no longer does. According to https://github.com/aspnet/DotNetTools/issues/404 the new format for ASP.NET Core 2.0 is:

```
   "Kestrel (dotnet watch run)": {
      "commandName": "Executable",
      "executablePath": "C:\\Program Files\\dotnet\\dotnet.exe",
      "commandLineArgs": "watch run",
      "workingDirectory": "C:\\Users\\namc\\source\\repos\\WebApplication2\\WebApplication2",
      "launchBrowser": true,
      "launchUrl": "https://localhost:5001/",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
      }
    }
```

The problem with this is the hard coded `executablePath` which is Windows specific and the `workingDirectory` which is specific to wherever I did a Git clone on my local machine.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support dotnet watch in launchSettings.json" (#1067)

Issues.Title: Nesting bug
Issues.Body:
The is a problem nesting embedded resources.  I was experimenting with nesting .cshtml files using the existing rules and did this:

Modal.cs (bootstrap modal web component)
   -> Modal.cs.cshtml (it's view file)

`Modal.cs.cshtml` is set to Embedded Resource, and clearly shows it, but is completed IGNORED by the build process (simply open the DLL in a text editor [such as Notepad++] and scroll to the bottom and look for text).  If I rename the file to "Modal.cshtml" instead it works perfectly fine!  :/  I don't think whether or not a file is embedded should have and role in excluding a file from being embedded so this seems like a bug to me.

Yes, I'm aware of upcoming nesting controls in v15.6, but I'm not able to install it yet, and regardless, this should work fine, so it should be looked into nonetheless.

Just to add: I'm using wild-cards to include the file.  If I explicitly add it I get this:

`Duplicate 'EmbeddedResource' items were included. ...`

So it's clearly found.  It's obviously something up with the build process not finding the nested file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nesting bug" (#1066)

Issues.Title: Views in class libraries removed from embedded resources under certain circumstances
Issues.Body:
I have a test repo which should hopefully demonstrate this problem, and I hope this is the correct repo for the issue.

https://github.com/svallis/precompilation-classlib

If you clone and open this solution and perform the following, the issue should be clear. First, the expected results is what happens when adding views to `app`:

- Go to `app1\Views\Home` and press SHIFT+F2 and create `Test.cshtml`
- Copy and paste the new file to end up with `Test - Copy.cshtml`
- Build the solution
- The `.csproj` file for `app1` remains unchanged

Now perform the same process on `lib1`:

- Go to `lib1\Views\Shared` and press SHIFT+F2 and create `Test.cshtml`
- Copy and paste the new file to end up with `Test - Copy.cshtml`
- Build the solution
- The `.csproj` file for `lib1` has the following added to it

```
<ItemGroup>
    <EmbeddedResource Remove="Views\Shared\Test - Copy.cshtml" />
</ItemGroup>
```

As you can imagine this is highly frustrating during development, and we're constantly running into it while developing features within a library. I don't know if it's an outright bug, or whether we could improve the existing rules in the `.csproj` for the library. Whatever changes are made to the library project file need to preserve existing functionality though, so that views are not included in the publish output and are embedded in the assembly. This allows everything to work both during development and after publishing with precompiled views.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Views in class libraries removed from embedded resources under certain circumstances" (#1058)

Issues.Title: Docker tools fail if multiple TFMs in project file
Issues.Body:
If you modify your projects to have multiple frameworks with the `<TargetFrameworks>` tag, then the Docker tools does not know which framework to use as there is no `<TargetFramework>` tag.

Adding the `<TargetFramework>`netcoreapp1.1`<...>` fixes the problem in Visual Studio and all the frameworks build and can debug with Docker.

However, if you try and build a framework other than the netcoreapp1.1 with the DotNet CLI, it fails as it, as the documentation states, will ignore the `<TargetFrameworks>` tag if the `<TargetFramework>` tag is present
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Docker tools fail if multiple TFMs in project file" (#1056)
